Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Minimally Invasive Interventional Radiological Techniques in Colorectal Cancer Metastases

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment through sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases unsuitable for surgical resection.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group underwent portal vein embolization, radioembolization, or ablation, while the control group received standard chemotherapy.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of minimally invasive interventional radiological techniques as alternative treatments.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the increase in future liver remnant volume (FLR) over a 6-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment through sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant increase in FLR (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 5% in the intervention group and 3% in the control group experiencing minor complications.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Cancer Institute.
